job_title: Marketing Manager in Penn Pitt, PA
pros: The pay was very competitive.
cons:
Woof ... there's a lot. First, this place has terrible work-life balance. The department is poorly organized and so everything is a fire drill. 

People work late into the evenings, they work on weekends, they answer emails on their days off. It is a very small staff for the size of the organization, and everyone wears a lot of hats and works constantly. You will be pressured into doing the same. 

Everything operates on a shoestring budget with outsized goals. There's very little structure in place to support more sophisticated marketing activities. As a result, everyone just sort of keeps the lights on. From a marketing perspective, there's not really a compelling message or coherent theme. They sell paint but they don't really want to market around that. The branding is terrible. The creative is terrible, etc. Everyone is very stuck in their ways. 

The company is very decentralized so they have a hard time developing a unified message or even figuring out what they have to say. Everything is highly fragmented. 

Turnover is very high overall, particularly on the digital side. As much as I hate the term "culture" this place has none. 

Most of all, if work-life balance is something that matters to you, I would strongly consider NOT working at PPG.

pros:
Having over 45,000 employees there are many wonderful people to work with across business units.
Nice 401K match. 
Benefits are on par with what you would expect from a company. Some teams in IT can finally do a work from home day with a lot of conditions in place.
cons:
Too many managers within each department resulted in several barely contributing to the company goals, typically common to see direct reports picking up the slack, with no credit for the efforts. It was not uncommon to see managers take credit to receive 10k bonuses EOY. Why some teams consisting of 6-10 people have two managers is beyond me. 

Some managers were instructed not to give anything over a 3 out of 5 for most bonus opportunities. Managers are rarely held accountable with employees being blamed for projects being late. 

Outsourcing is becoming more popular within the company, especially with Oracle. Acquisitions have also resulted in several job cuts.

review_title: My experience as a bottom level employee is barely tolerable. We seem to be the company slaves.
pros: My coworkers are very friendly and extremely hardworking. We feel like family. The benefits are okay, and I personally like the kind of work we do.
cons: We are never thanked for a job well done, and in fact are always talked down to and treated like children. We're only allowed to clock out when dismissed. We are used to scrub the production floor or to do tasks no-one else wants to do. Mandatory over-time is understandable at times but gets used far too much. Especially when most of the employees are willing to put in over-time voluntarily. There are also obvious favorites, that are allowed to do almost anything, such as chew gum, whereas, someone else may be written up for it. In other words, there's no consistency.

pros: Quality of life, car, benefits were ok.
cons:
It was surprising to see a company so large, be so incompetent when it comes to basic field operations.  The Pro team was destine to fail due to lack of (Internal) support, Pro focused products and THD buy in.  

The only hope hope for this channel to recoup some credibility would be to realize what brand you have (Pro or consumer), the customer (Leadership may want to take a day or two in the field at some point) and craft a balanced approach (Sales, Marketing, Logistics, Supply, etc...) that allow sales people to sell to the people that need the product WHEN they need it.  Otherwise you're going to see more rounds of cutting people in the field.  It's simply not a sustainable way to go to business.

The truth is, the competition does not focus on PPG/Glidden because they don't have to.  They know that the probability of the sales person (TM or PSR) being there for any length of time is pretty slim.  

Do yourself a favor and stay away from a company that is so disorganized and reckless when it comes to it's people.   This company strives to point the finger, threaten and instill fear.

pros: If you're willing to take on other people's work and stay over to finish you'll gain tons of experience. My coworkers were nice and conveyed a family oriented atmosphere in my department. Good place to gain experience even though compensation for the work may not be available. Okay benefits.
cons: Management does not communicate well. They expect you to be a mind reader and will blame you for not understanding what they are trying to say. If you're not careful management will walk over you and supervisors will take credit for work that you completed. Pay is not competitive and raises are a joke. The company may have record breaking profits but they will still only give you a 1.5% raise. Management is very sneaky and will make unpopular decisions and then have a meeting to reiterate that there's nothing you can do about the changes and that you'll just have to deal with it, but they understand that you're upset. No incentive for good employees to stay.

pros: Good opportunity to learn about yourself and how to "deal" with people from all levels and to learn what not to do in a work place or how to treat people.
cons: An extremely weak HR department that shows favoritism. If someone in management, HR or another supervisor doesn't like you or sees you as a threat you won't last there. Too many friends and family from production employees to the management team. A completely incompetent management team that reacts too much without thinking about the long term effects of a given situation. Complete disregard for your interests even though they will tell you they care about your growth which is not true because they have already chosen their favorites on who they want to help move up.

review_title: Depends which group you work for.
pros: Large well known company with strong resources. Very strong at product marketing, Company prefers to hire people right out of college so can be a good option for a first job.
cons:
If you are working in a division that is doing well PPG can be a good company to work for. But if your division is not doing well your life will miserable.  
Most managers are long term employee's and they do everything the PPG way even when there were better options.  I saw many employee's dedicated to doing whatever they felt necessary to keep their jobs and not what was best for the business.
In the group I was in being over 50 greatly increased your chances of being forced out. Some companies value highly experienced employees. But in the division I was at over 50 meant you were making a higher salary and that was not good.

review_title: I would avoid it, if possible
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Allison Park, PA
pros: Great coworkers, the first few months are great
cons:
It seems like the company is pushing out many upper level chemists and pulling in more recently graduated Ph.D's with no experience. There also seems like there is very little room for contractors to get a job within the company if they want to. Many times if someone that is already full time at PPG applies to the same position,  the first choice is normally the full time employee. I took this job out of college because I wanted to get some experience but I think I would have rather kept my part time job over doing this job. Contractors get paid terribly, do not get paid vacation (they previously had but the contracting agency took it away), no paid holidays , and crappy health insurance. Like previously stated, if you can avoid being a contractor, I would. I regret every minute of it. 

Additionally, it seems like they are moving management around without having a clue who would fit in well where. I see unfair treatment between contractors and full time employees.

review_title: Not a bad company, bad managers
pros: Flexibility of schedule, Client has mostly good people, I have met some good people, holiday schedule generous
cons: You will be worked like a rented mule and treated as such by upper management. There is no regard for anything outside of your job, This company has been sued so many times that they are regimental in their requirements, if you disagree with something, you are told to be glad you have a job, no valid reasons given for decisions other that that is what the "team" has decided, management in a bind and you step up great, ask them to throw you a bone, don't bet on it. If you have ever worked for a competitor, expect to pay dearly for it, and heaven forbid you still have friends from that company, you will be expected to end the friendship. Management has embarrassed me to the point that I have made a call to someone to apologize for his bad behavior.

review_title: Stay far away from this company
pros: not much except 401(k), paid vacation, benefits
cons: A bunch of spoiled employees who will back stab you and get you in trouble with management for their benefit.  Different rules for different employees, if you have been there for 25+ years, you have one set of rules, employees with less than 10 years have a different set of rules.  Make all employees follow the rules no matter how long they have been employed there.  Very difficult to move from one department to another, once you are hired in, good luck trying to move out of that position.  Unfair compensation, they will pay a new hire more than what you were hired in for, even if they started a month after you. Be expected to work mandatory overtime on weekends and on major holidays, not family friendly, company does not care about their employees.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Scarborough, ON
pros:
-Great people
-Great atmosphere
-Get to know your customers on a more personal level because you see many of them on a regular basis, sometimes they bring coffees and treats
-If you like paint and colour mixing, it's fun
-You get to deal with retail customers as well as business owners
-Paid overtime
-Physical
cons:
-Very physical
-Upper management only cares about making money; people on the sales floor doing the ground work are underappreciated
-Hard to score a full-time position
-Many stores are understaffed
-Little room to climb even though they say there's many opportunities for promotion
-Garbage raises ($0.25/year, if that, and it depends on how your store does overall, not based on each individual employee)
-Employee turnover is INSANE

review_title: Good company but underpaid and abused
job_title: Pro Sales Representative in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great benefits, company car, expense accounts, consisitent pay.
cons: less than median pay, unattainable sales goals, cap on sales bonus, no matter how much or how well you do always demanding more. No consistence ever leadership with negativity and by fear of losing job.

review_title: General Industrial - Does not care about their employees
job_title: Field Service Tech in Nashville, TN
pros: The job they hire you for will start you at a a good salary and benefits for the work that you will do. They will provide you with everything that you need and you will be expected to work without supervision.
cons: You salary advancement is limited and if you get to the midpoint of you salary range, they will not add merit increases to your income. They will give you a lump sum check of whatever your raise was but will not add anything else to you income until they raise you to the next pay Band. In other words, the amount you will get paid will is capped and the amount put into your retirement is capped until they move you Band. This only happens if your manager puts you in for a move up and upper managers allow your pay band to be changed.

pros: Experience and travel. Most store managers are good people, it's hard to watch them be worked so hard though. It's easy to track how well your store is doing. Communication within the company is pretty good, except they make it seem as though they care when, by their actions, it's clear they do not.
cons: Pay is bad, micro-management to the extreme, must travel or take jobs you don't want to stay employed, harassment in a male dominated field, absolutely no help when hurt on the job - workers compensation supplies the worst care and for only a few months even if your injury is long lasting. My list could go on, having this job was the biggest waste of my time. Wish I never took the job.

review_title: Solid experience filled with people who want you to succeed
pros:
Manager wants you to succeed.
Leaning all of the basics of the job early on.
The program sets you up with a professional network with a mentor as well as other FLD's.
There is flex time and schedules are flexible to a point. 
I feel like family is valued and so is your overall health. 
There are many growth opportunities but it is your job to look for them and take advantage of them
The benefits package covers a good amount for health, dental, vision and car. 
Higher Education is encouraged and PPG will help you pay for it. 
The upper management likes to know what is going on to the plant level. This always tells you their level of interest in making their company succeed.
cons:
Some jobs can be monotomous. 
The culture is one sided. Meaning there aren't many young professionals
It took a little longer than I would have wanted to build a training schedule
Compensation could be higher.
Mobility is the key to move forward, Could be a pro or con depending on how you feel about this

review_title: Awesome job. Crappy office in Brno.
pros:
Large company, american-like approach, constantly growing and providing interesting challenges.
From the work load and composition point of view, it's perfect. Ongoing projects, new acquisitions, fluid IT environment which can be subjected to redesign and tweaking, lots of room to have an IT specialist put his innovative spirit into play.
cons:
1. Local office policies in Brno.
2. Local office policies in Brno.
3. Local office policies in Brno.
4. Local office policies in Brno.
and so on. 

While i understand the purpose of the Brno location is to have back-office financial services, extending the policies to all personnel that works there is a poor decision.

review_title: Management is disconnected from the work the employees they manage
job_title: Systems Analyst I in Louisville, KY
pros:
-- Good benefits overall - good heath & dental insurance, excellent retirement contribution (100% on the first 6% of your salary)
-- Compensation seems good; there's always an annual bonus
cons:
-- PPG denied my retention bonus. We had a signed agreement that they kept amending by extending the date to which I had to work to receive the bonus. I worked for over a year until I had had enough and left.
-- There is no maturity in the IT department (where I worked) to improve processes. They continue to do things the same way without any forethought on how to make processes more efficient or resolving the root issues (more the band-aid solutions)
-- They run a lean IT shop; With all the acquisitions, it's a tough place to work. The IT managers don't really understand the technology and areas they manage.

review_title: Territory Manager - Architectural Coatings Home center Division
pros:
Excellent benefits
company car 
opportunity to move within company
easy job - tasks
cons:
They have an entire HR department devoted to Territory Managers who are not hitting numbers. They don't go by calendar year they go by a rolling 6 months.  So you can still be up for the year but have 3 negative months and boom on a PIP. unheard of! 
RSM can control your destiny. Under previous RSM I was on track for a promotion. New RSM came aboard and all promotional opportunities were denied. This is NOT the case in all areas but specifically in Chicago.
Never have I been this stressed out over sales numbers when you really don't have that much to be able to influence.

pros:
-Competitive pay
-Awesome insurance options (Aetna and BlueShield)
-Competitive 401(k) or IRA contribution matches (up to 6%)
-Streamlined support lines, employee benefit enrollment, online paystubs, etc.
cons:
-Hard to move up without the hard years of experience and/or acknowledgement from your boss and your bosses boss
-Physically hard at first if you are used to a sedentary lifestyle since the job involves plenty of lifting, warehousing and customer service (carrying paint for customers, mixing the paint quickly so that you can serve the next customer in a timely manner, etc.)
-The current computer system sucks hard, and is not straightforward or intuitive in any way. Takes time to learn
-The phone system sucks and you learn quickly that with no caller ID, you need to be good at taking notes about orders, questions, comments, etc.

pros: Not many... I guess if I had to mention one it would be work/life balance.  Stores mostly closed on weekends and reps not expected to work.
cons: Clueless middle and upper management is the biggest one.  Also, company paid considerably less than most competitors.  No organization chart, no HR support, no LP presence.  No room for advancement as they constantly look outside the company instead of promoting from within.  For such a large company, benefits are average at best and pretty expensive.  No appreciation from middle and upper management for delivering results.  Instead they like to either nitpick you over little things or say nothing at all and get rid of you.  Little or no training provided as middle management is completely incompetent and have no clue where to start.  I could go on and on.... stay away from the stores division unless you like being treated with little respect, like being underpaid and underappreciated, and enjoy being taught next to nothing but expected to deliver results.

review_title: A stable company providing stable employment where you wait for people to retire or die before you move up.
job_title: Systems Analyst I in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Stable Company, 401K, Flexible Hours. HR, Benefits, Expense systems are all on-line. People rarely leave which provides consistency.
cons:
There is a very old-school mentality where breaking from the status quo is not accepted.
If you want paid market rate, you need to be hired from outside, otherwise raises are rare and  not much. The annual dividend is marketed as stability, but is really an excuse to reward large stockholders when it could be used to reward employees. There is too much group think and going outside the box doesn't bode well. It is impossible to get fired unless you are caught in the act of something against the rules, but even that is debatable. Performance ratings are based on a bell curve and not actual performance.

pros:
Salary is okay if you manage to negotiate it.
International exposure, variety of countries where the company operates.
cons:
People lack professionalism, both in HQ and especially in regional offices. Salaries are not competitive in the market on average, so they cannot hire top class people. My manager was the worst in my 20 years career. Every day was a fight for a common sense.
At the same time they are promoting 'Women leadership' policy, which led to hiring of many unprofessional but well-paid managers and directors.
Corporate culture is a kind of strange. Not very open, people afraid to take responsibility. Arrogant old school, grey hair managers.
Employees officially call PPG "Poor People's Group" because the company do not care about them. They dispose people without any respect. Many cases when people went to the court to claim what they had to get according to their contracts.
Locations of offices and plants is a disaster.
The company has a lot of problems and grows only because of huge acquisitions.
In short, very average company, nothing special, without bright and smart people, with very typical American culture. 
However, many people are happy to work there, and do not want anything better.

pros:
It is not a bad place to work. The 24/7 positions are not bad
Parking is free.
cons:
The pay is terrible. From a company that makes so much money you think you be able to survive while working here and not have to get a second Job. 

Also they over pay people who do allot less work. I started around 20 and the guy that got hired the same day as me was getting over 30. 

the dead end aspect of it is bad too. The other teams do not want to take from my area because they think we get paid too much. Also with any promotion it is only 10%. No matter if you are moving from tier 1 to tier 3. 

i feel if you want to have a good enterprise on your resume work here for 2 years then move asap.

pros: Strong financially, the largest paint manufacturer in the world. Good products, especially the HDIM line. Acquisitions in last several years have added better-known brands and formulations(Glidden, Flood). Good dealer and stores network.
cons:
Lack of diversity- if you attend a sales conference, you notice that upper management is primarily middle aged men. Very few women and minorities. 

The company is top heavy with management, which is not particularly integrated with the field personnel; sales and profit objectives are difficult to obtain that way. There was a lot of talent lost with the Akzo integration, as many people from Akzo facilities (and from PPG facilities) did not want to move to Western Pennsylvania. 

There is a lack of product promotion, which could be better. The intimidation with big box retailers (HD) may backfire at some point.

review_title: Great place to start a career or the whole thing! Beware if you are finically driven this is not the gig for you, safe.
pros: Great established company steeped in tradition and generations of success. Lots of room for growth.
cons: Not a great place for 6 digit sales jobs.  All roads eventually lead to Pittsburgh, or worse yet in AC, Louisville.  AC is the red headed stepchild of PPG and is not treated the same as if you were in a different SBU, mostly due to larger number of reps.  Don't even consider working for the Lowes division unless you have little ambition and enjoy working in a bib box.

review_title: You will hurt your career here.
pros: Decent benefits. Good pay. Stable employment
cons: Many managers have been here forever-some its their first job and they will retire here. They can't wrap their head around any other ideas, thoughts or way of doing things. Very outdated IT infastructure. There's no org chart, and if you have a problem outside your department, you likely won't know who to call for help. Office politics are very high. Senior managers are often mean to employees because the company does not reprimand or fire people outright, so they get away with it. The business revolves around accounting and month-end. If you are not an accountant, you will be expected to be one. Since the company doesn't fire anyone, there's a lot of dead weight lingering in offices. Because department managers refuse to communicate, there's a lot of duplicate work. Louisville is the red headed step child of ppg. Corporate does not like this business unit.

pros: People in the Material Department, Great team. Without them, This plant would lose even more money than it already is losing. Outstanding HR lady
cons: Never enough people to do the jobs. Hire right out of prison. The fights are spectacular, knives, guns, and lots of pot smoking. Upper management has no clue as to what is going on with day to day operations. Terrible pay for the average worker. Know one is held accountable for anything. No training learn it yourself.  Absolutely No work Life balance here. They also do nothing about harassment complaints. There Ethic department what a joke they just sweep it under the rug. As a Manager you are set up to fail everyday. You might as well apply for Firefighting because that's all you will do there.

job_title: Senior Systems Analyst in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: stable, pay is reasonable, bonus is OK, 401K is OK.  If you want to become a nameless, faceless cog in a huge machine, and not have to work too hard, this might be the place for you.  Seriously, this is not a dis....  You can hide here and if you have a minimal intelligence, you can do fine.... but it is a big corporation, and you will have to deal with big corporation attitudes to get anywhere...
cons: Company does not have a focused technology vision.  IT resources are just that - resources - interchangeable, and have not much value other than the ability to do the coding necessary.

pros: Pretty easy job, low stress most of the time, make your own schedule, company car and phone
cons: Pay is dirt cheap, I don't know what this company does with its profits certainly not pay its employees. No work life balance, you can make your daily scheduled but you must work Fridays and Saturdays at least 8 hour days year around. Leaves no time for workers to have with their families. Bonus plan is nothing to get excited about. Marketing does a poor job of getting our name out there and TMs are expected to achieve all the sales gains by them selves and when they don't no raise as all. Even if you hit your numbers, when I did j got a 2-3% raise those years but PPG says they give pay increases on performance??

review_title: Good Springboard for interns and co-ops to move on to the next company in their career.
pros: Huge exposure to a wide variety of personalities, ideas; great place to cut your teeth and gain exposure to corporate politics, sensitivity, learn about the real reasons why HR departments  exist. Great place to learn how to "play the game" and grow some thick skin.
cons: Fear culture, favoritism, people moved around and promoted on tenure rather than skill set and performance. If you can "play the game" and have a high tolerance for working with bureaucracy at its finest and if you like to attend meeting after meeting that has nothing to do with you or your projects then this is the place for you!

job_title: A V P in New York, NY
pros: Hours are OK most of the time. People are generally reasonable and responsive; not as crazy as at some other places I've worked. Good vacation policies (4 weeks) and you get to take them with little or grief given. Some opportunity to work from home or out of the office, especially as you move up the ladder and if your presence in the office isn't physically necessary.
cons: Place is so big and constantly reorganizing with seemingly little rhyme or reason. The bureacracy often gets in the way of the job, but rarely helps when it should, as when a senior person breaks the "rules" s/he gets no grief and, in fact,  gets to complain about lack of initiative, etc. If lower level person tries to exercise some initiative, often is beaten down.

review_title: Management didn't plan or prepare for a business expansion, causing many unknowns and a tremendous amount of stress.
pros: No no no no no
cons: "Training" consisted of a verbal brain dump from one person to another. A significant amount of information was not documented for reference, while the documented information was often out of date. In most instances, new hires didn't get an opportunity to practice a newly "learned" skill before they were responsible for executing it. New hires were assigned to shifts without supervisors, and had no way to contact anyone with experience should a question or problem arise. Management asked for feedback and suggestions, and often agreed to make changes, but then repeatedly didn't carry through. The persons who were promoted were the ones who generated the largest amount of completed work regardless of accuracy, even though we were told that quality was more important than quantity. All of these issues created a very tense, difficult environment in which to work.

review_title: Company out of touch with their business
pros: Many good, hard working, resourceful people on the front lines of this company. People who are dedicated and a joy to be around.
cons: Management that motivates poorly, overlooks qualified people, promotes on the basis of personal preference over performance, and is demeaning to their subordinates. They tell you that they want your honest input, but as soon as someone voices their opinion they are labeled as having a negative attitude or not a team player.

pros: - benefits are comparable to other strong companies
cons:
- fraught with tension among internal management
- culturally disjointed 
- lack of strong leadership
- promotion based solely on demographic requirements (not accomplishments)
- poor training in some areas
- overlooking abusive treatment from internal customers (colleagues/ other departments)

review_title: Strong Company, Good Opportunities, Archaic Business Practices
pros: When you get a job with PPG, you don't have to worry about losing it. It's hard to get your foot in the door, but once you do, they try to keep you in. It's a large company, and they are currently struggling to recruit, so there is & will be lots of room for advancement now and as the baby boomers begin to retire. The pay is decent and the benefits are good.
cons: Their way of treating employees is very outdated. Good performance ratings are restricted to a certain percentage of the company. If you and all of your co-workers do an awesome job, it looks like you're going to have to alternate the good performance reviews & bonus escalations from year-to-year. There is minimal investment in the quality of the workplace.

review_title: It's a job, nothing more than that.
pros: They have decent benefits, not the best I've had, but not the worst either. The pay is pretty good and they offer annual bonus incentives.
cons: The worst part about working here is the 10 minute walk from the parking lot to the building, seriously a third of a mile walk. It's not bad during the summer, but the winters in Cleveland are brutal and that walk in the snow is the best way to ruin an entire day. Majority of the people have worked here 30-40 years. If your just out of college no one will take you seriously. As far as training, it's horrible. It doesn't exist. There is no room for new hires in this office. They literally have three people crammed into offices big enough for one person.

pros: If you can get into the Accelerated Training Program, it will be worth your time. You will move to  a variety of divisions in the company, with success and an in house mentor throughout your career. PPG promotes from within whenever possible and their stock program (when active) is excellent.
cons: If you are not in the ATP program, it is a little more difficult to get promoted. Hard work is one thing, but being in the program(the future of the company) is yet another. Once you get to a certain level there are many "who you know" types of personalities. This may be commonplace in very large organizations.

pros: It is a company with great potential. And I think their current leaders understand that to achieve the vision they will employ people that are passionate about every aspect of the business and most of all have a true desire to help the progress of humanity and turn PPG into a household name.
cons: A bit of a challenge to break through the resitance to change and no real creativity in how to create brand awarness.

review_title: Its a lot of work but it is rewarding
pros: I liked everyone I worked with. People are usually friendly and helpful. If you like to stay busy, this is a good job for you. They do offer free higher education, stipulated that you must stay with the company at least 5 years after you get your degree.
cons: It can be boring to stay at the same department for many years. After a while you master your position and there is little growth to be made. They do offer first dibs internally for new jobs but it can be hard to meet the qualifications. Management likes to hear from workers regarding new ideas to improve work flow. But new ideas are rarely implemented. I even won an award for a contribution that was never put into practice.

pros: There is some work/life balance in terms of leaving early for appointments and you can work from home as needed, but it wasn't something that was encouraged. My coworkers were incredible in every aspect. They are hard working and extremely helpful.
cons: Management is absolutely horrible. If you want to work somewhere where your opinion means nothing this is the place for you. They are overworked and have no time for you. Finding your manager is a challenge because they are never in their office and if they are the door is closed. The CFO is so disrespectful to his team and changes his story depending on who he is talking to. Everything is politics driven and bottom line driven.

pros: Decent starting pay for manual labor at a DC
cons: Too many useless employees standing around while others work. Many employees use intimidation and accusations to get others in trouble. Middle and upper management seems afraid to confront and dismiss these people and punish others instead. Middle management clueless as to what goes on on a day to day basis. Work standards are not evenly enforced. Advancement is purely based on your ability to brown nose. Mandatory overtime is instituted way to often, when hiring a few more people or making people pull their weight would eliminate the need.

job_title: Business Development Manager in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Overall, great people to work with. Excellent products
cons: Prices are very cheap compared to competitors. Fewer locations compared to competitors. Not all locations stock the same products. Constantly using PIP as motivation for reps. Company direction was not made clear. Multiple product lines that are very similar which confuses customers as well as employees. Focusing on low price battles rather than quality and service. Minimal staff.

review_title: Great benefits coming from a polluting, socially unconcious company.
pros: There are top-notch benefits for full-time employees.  It is a fairly straight-forward objective, to get quality paint to customers when they need it.  The management is top-down, if you like that sort of thing.
cons: Culture is conservative, and also VERY anti-environment.  They actually have a voting page to tell you which candidates to vote for who are consistent in voting against air and water quality regulation, and they are against the Environmental Protection Agency!!  Also, the company is one of the highest polluting non-energy entities in the state, even though they just make automotive paint.  Working for PPG, you can expect an ambiguous set of expectations to live by, and a culture of me-against-you that ensures that if you do something "wrong", someone will tell on you for it!

review_title: Opportunity to shine - but overcoming business unit silos is a challenge
job_title: Director, Sales & Ops in Toronto, ON
pros:
Good technical company with great finance skills and a growing acknowledgement of the importance of sales excellence.  People who deliver results will get the opportunity to move up.
The company is very ethical.  Training is good: HR works hard to identify good outside training opportunities and to develop good internal ones.
cons: The company has multiple business units and each operates a lot like a separate company - there are some silo issues.  Cross-business unit (XSBU) selling effort was a great idea, but was met with lukewarm interest by many managers.  There are limited opportunities (beyond the superstars and beyond the Pittsburgh area) to  take on challenges in different SBU's.

pros:
Able to make own schedule 
Health care ok
Good stepping stone to get into territory management. However can dull you sales skills as they are not used like they should be.
cons: They care more about the investors than you. You are paid in the mid 30s you will not get more than a 10% pay bump when promoting to a new position. No match on 401k. They auto enroll you for a % of your income but no match. Hourly job which includes a lot of detailed time card management. Most of our competitors territory reps are salary which is consistent with the industry. The first and last hour of drive time is not paid that is 10 hours a week in the car you are not paid for. Constantly wanting the territory managers saving money meanwhile corporate spends like crazy including unnecessary marketing materials. Not very diverse employee pool. HR is not friendly. All policy are written to benefit PPG.

pros:
-They pay you well to relocate
-Very flexible on hours
-Good work schedule,  Mon-Fri 7am-5pm
-Competitive pay $37,000
cons: When you first interview for the position they make the opportunities seem amazing and getting placed is a piece of cake.  Just to give you a little background, this Career Development Program, or CDP as we are referred to,  is basically in a temporary position.  Once you complete the 6 month training program you have 6 months to find a store.  Now what the don't tell you is that completing the training program is the easy part and that finding a store is a very intense process.  Even though you were hired on and be trained to be a manager doesn't mean you will have any preference over other candidates applying to the same management position.  So once you complete the program you go to the careers web page and look for openings all across the country.  Keep in mind there are 30 other candidates in your class that you are competing against for these positions.  Once you find a store you would like to apply to next you have to see if it is CDP eligible.   Basically it can't be a brand new store and it can't be over a million dollars in sales.  By the way there is a person in charge of the CDP program who is supposed to help you get placed,  well he does very little, I mean you are on you own.   Finally after you apply to a store you go through a formal interview process like you would with any other job and than they say you the our doing more interviews and will make a decision by the end of the week.  A couple different scenarios usually occur.  One,  they let you know in an email that you were not a good fit for the position,  Two,  you never hear anything from them again.

pros:
This is a huge organization with numerous opportunities for horizontal movement.  You'll be exposed to a large a talented pool of very skilled colleagues.  The people are great and seem to truly care deeply about their job and the company. 
The recently resigned CEO has done a fantastic job of overseeing a sustained period of growth driven mostly by strategic acquisitions and divestitures which has evolved the company into a wide range specialty coatings company. This has lead to excellent stock performance.
cons: Sadly, senior management seems detached from reality. It's a very traditional company, with outdated views on technology and growth. They grow by acquisition.  Innovation is stalled by rigid procedures, and political maneuvering.  The company has several interesting and potentially innovative market segments, but they have siloed these SBU's and segments so deeply that only real vanguards with a disregard for internal obstacles can bridge these gaps to cross SBU and cross segment success.  Because they seem almost knee-jerk reactionary In making personnel changes when something changes in the market, employees seem averse to making any decisions that might make them standout, for total fear of failure. To say the culture is risk averse is a huge understatement. Pay is very uncompetitive.  Due to the huge number of employees who have begun their career with PPG and remained there through a willingness to accept any assignment given, there's a lack of understanding about the global jobs marketplace or pay scales. job_title: Senior Systems Analyst in Pittsburgh, PA

Decent opportunities for new positions and career changes so long as you don't mind situations where they have already selected a candidate rather than interviewing for one.

cons: PPG suffers from many of the same tragedies as  many of the big global corporations.  Poor middle management who ride the success of their employees, a lot of overpaid dinosaurs who are protected by the good ole boy network, and senior management who get high returns on short term decisions with long term negative consequences. job_title: Service Desk Analyst in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: The people are generally friendly. After a few months of getting familiar, your day-to-day gets fairly routine. The pay is nice, though I'm not familiar enough with benefits packages to say if PPG's is nice or competitive. They do a good job of accommodating vacation time, and scheduling is fairly flexible granted you are able to find a coworker to cover your shift. PPG looks very good on a resume.
cons:
You will not work this position for more than 2 years, which could either be a good thing or a bad thing depending on your circumstance. 

Quality focus is more geared toward bringing in newer and cheaper workers than they are capable of providing clear, relevant, and ongoing coaching to develop quality workers for long term. Couple this with a new director of IT who seems less interested with in-house development than their predecessor, I have a difficult time expressing optimism for long-term employment to entry level workers.

Quality reviews seem more like a chance to nitpick bland details and lower your performance score than they are about identifying and correcting recurring shortcomings.

After interviewing for similar positions, it started to become clear to me that very few of the tasks I had been performing throughout my day to day were in-depth enough to transfer between jobs. You will get surface level experience in a ton of unfamiliar systems. You will have an impressive looking resume. You will not have trouble getting another interview. But I find it unlikely to have enough in-depth understanding of the applications/procedures you support to "talk the talk." 

You will be sharing equipment (keyboards, mice, headsets, desks, etc) with everyone in the office. Germaphobes beware.

You will subject yourself to random drug screenings via hair sample.

A 1 hour unpaid lunch is mandatory when working normal daylight hours, lunch breaks are not technically scheduled during off hours because it is assumed you will eat at your desk between calls.
